Assignments.answer: Unless you use the Special Extension Coupon (giving you a five-day reprieve), assignments handed in late (without medical documentation) will be penalized at 5% per day (max. 25% per week). Assignments are no longer accepted after five days (including weekends). In the case of special circumstances, please contact your TA or your instructor.

examples: How do I know a publication is scholarly?
I dont know if i have chosen a scholarly article
What is a scholarly article
Which articles are considered scholarly
Assignments.answer: A scholarly article is always published in a peer-reviewed journal. You know the journal is peer-reviewed either because the York Library entry identifies it as such (just above the "Available Online" link) or the journal's website says so, usually under "About us" or "Submission Guidelines." The easiest way to know is probably to filter your journals search in York Library’s database by clicking on “Peer Reviewed Journals.” Note: An article is not a book, encyclopedia entry, review or opinion.

Assignments.answer: You will have to find your own article. The easiest way to find scholarly articles is through the York Library website or Google Scholar. It doesn’t matter where you find the scholarly article as long as you include true scholarly articles in your assignments.

Assignments.answer: You can change your topic from the Scholarly Article Review to Essay 1 or from the Annotated Bibliography to Essay 2 without asking permission from the instructor. It’s never too late to do so. The only drawback if you do so is that you cannot use the article(s) from the previous assignment, as they are no longer related to your new topic. But you do have that flexibility.

Assignments.answer: Choose a topic you’re interested in for the assignments. If the topic is explicitly related to one of the modules (from the first half of the course for the article review and Essay 1, the second half of the course for the annotated bibliography and Essay 2), then the topic is fine. If it deviates from this, you absolutely need to get the instructor’s approval.

examples: Can you  tell me more about HUMA 1740
Can you tell me more about the course?
What is the course about?
What is The Roots of Modern Canada about?
What is HUMA 1740 about?
Can you  tell me more about The Roots of Modern Canada
CourseDescrip.answer:
This course explores the ideas and events that shaped Canada, and the modes of expression that embodied them over the centuries. It also addresses situations that fall short of the ideas and ideals that permeate national consciousness. Canada is a multilayered entity, a compromise of differences that defies any unified description. It should be considered in relation to indigeneity, race, colonial and linguistic duality, regionalism, multiculturalism, multinationalism, and democratic principles, among other concepts. None of these perspectives can make sense of the country on their own, and even taken together, they still stubbornly resist any cohesive view. Our understanding can hope to be “as Canadian as possible, under the circumstances,” as the quip goes.

This course is not a history of Canada although, ideas being steeped in the past, historical enquiry will figure prominently. Canada will be the focal point of study in this context, drawing from many disciplinary fields such as history, geography, philosophy, history of ideas, literature, art, political science, etc.

Discussion.answer: If you don't participate in the group discussion, you get and automatic 0 while the rest of the group receives a group mark. (It doesn't make sense to receive marks for something you didn't do, right?) If you participate in the discussion notes, you may get a partial grade if you speak to your TA about it prior to the absence.

examples: Required reading for the discussion

Help with discussion notes
not sure if my discussion notes are correct
What should discussion notes include
Discussion.answer: Discussion and discussion questions are based on the reading (not the Contextual Notes presented in class). Make sure to consider your questions from all possible perspectives and draw from the reading. References (i.e. citations) to the reading in the discussion notes are useful because they support the points the group will be making in the discussion. That said, you can ask a question that goes beyond the text if it allows you to better understand the text itself.

examples: Who should submit the discussion note?
My group member submitted our discussion notes. Do I also have to submit myself?
Is it one submission per group for discussion notes
discussion notes submission
do all group members have to submit their discussion notes
How do I submit my discussion notes
Discussion.answer: Taking notes is a group effort, and groups normally use a Google document to write down notes during the discussion. However, only one person submits the notes for the whole group. It is the back-up person’s responsibility to submit the notes for the group. If she is not present on that day, then the presenter submits the discussion notes. If for some reason neither of them is present, it's up to the group to determine who should submit the notes. Failing to do so would result in the whole group getting a 0, so don't forget!

cannot find my grades on eclass
eClass.answer: You can see both detailed grades from a specific course or grades for all your courses, published by your course instructor. To see your grades for all of your courses, you’ll see a red arrow to the right of your name at the top right corner of eClass. Click on the red arrow, then click on “Grades” from the expanded menu, and you’ll see a list of all your courses and their grades. To see grades for a specific course, simply click on a course from the Dashboard and then click on “Grades” in the top red ribbon.

eClassNav.answer:
All written assignments must be submitted electronically in eClass or else the TA and instructor will not be able to grade it. No email or printed paper are permitted.

Click on “Start”, then on the relevant assignment (e.g. “Essay 1: Delving Deeper”) under “Assignment”, “Add Submission”, drag and drop your assignment in the field and click on “Save Changes.” You can email an assignment only to prove that it was completed by a certain time if eClass is not accessible. However, the written assignment must subsequently be submitted online for it to be graded.

eClassNav.answer: To find the presentation schedule, click on “Start” and click on “Presentation Schedule” under the “Presentation” section. If you can reach the presentation schedule (it’s empty or you can’t see the schedule), it usually means you’ve not been assigned to a group. Your instructor will be happy to fix this.

need help with presentation submission
eClassNav.answer: To submit your class presentation, click on the “Start” button in eClass, then on “Evaluation of Presentation,” then on “Add a New discussion topic.” In the “Subject” field, write your group number and the module name of the presentation (e.g. “Group 2: Slavery in Canada”). In the “Message” field, please add your name and a short text (e.g. “Hi, this is my presentation for this week. John Doe”). Click on “Advanced” and drag your presentation document into the “Attachment” field. Finally, click on “Post to Forum.” Voilà!

Extension.answer:
The extension coupon is for five days (including weekends). On the following days after the five grace days, you get deducted 5% per late day up to 25%. After that, the paper is no longer accepted and you receive a 0. If you submitted the assignment within the five days of the extension coupon and still had grades deducted, there may have been a mistake. Your instructor or TA will be happy to clarify the matter.
To redeem the extension coupon, click Start, scroll down to 'Assignments,' and click 'Redeem Extension Coupon.' Once on the new page, click on 'Mark as done.' That’s it!

Grade.answer: The Registrar’s Office is responsible for the degree progress report. The instructor and TA have no control over the time needed to process the required information. The Degree Progress Report is currently available for a number of single-major programs. Go to the [Degree Progress Report](https://w6prod.sis.yorku.ca/yda/?utm_source=internal-query&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=SAVY) and enter your program to find your personalized report. If your program is not currently supported, or you have questions, you can reach out to the Registrar’s office for help. You can contact [Registrarial Services](https://currentstudents.yorku.ca/registrarial-services?utm_source=internal-query&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=SAVY) for help virtually by phone at 416-872-9675 ??, or [Live Chat](https://currentstudents.yorku.ca/registrarial-services?utm_source=internal-query&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=SAVY). If Live Chat is open, you'll see a Live Chat icon at the right side of the screen. If you don’t see it, Live Chat is closed at that time. You can also drop into the Bennett Centre in person. York also has a ton of [self-service tools](https://myonlineservices.students.yorku.ca?utm_source=internal-query&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=SAVY) you can use.

examples: Can I submit an essay written by chat gpt
chatGPT wrote my essay
Is chatGPT allowed at York
Will my assignment be accepted if I used chat GPT
Can I use ChatGPT?
Honesty.answer: You cannot use ChatGPT to generate a whole text on its own. However, you can use ChatGPT if it is helpful as a writing tool, but beware of its limitations! ChatGPT makes stuff up (and false information in an assignment is often grounds for flunking) and is too descriptive for the class assignments. A typical text generated by ChatGPT rarely meets the requirements described in the syllabus, resulting likely in a flunking grade. ChatGPT is best used for improving style and clarity of your text, not generating it the first place.

examples: course learning outcomes
list of things I will learn in this course
What will I be learning about in this course?
What wil I learn about in HUMA 1740?
What are the learning outcomes for the course?
LearnOutcomes.answer:
The learning outcomes for this course are:

1. To better understand current Canadian issues and debates by tracing them back to past cultural, political, and philosophical ideas and events
2. To acquire familiarity with varied works and cultural artifacts that define Canadian identity, including primary texts, comments, scholarly articles, novels, graphic novels, films, songs, etc.
3. To be able to interpret and critically assess these works in their historical, social, and political context
4. To improve one’s ability to read various types of texts, write academic papers and verbally articulate one’s own ideas and those of others (i.e. written and verbal communication skills)
5. To develop critical self-awareness of assumptions and values that shape one’s understanding and interpretation of cultural artefacts
6. To develop an appreciation for primary works that influenced contemporary Canadian discussions
7. To identify scholarly articles dealing with a variety of topics

Presentation.answer: If your presentation is ready, but you can't present for any reason, you should send a message to your backup for that day. Ideally, you would send her or him your presentation notes as well. It might be possible to switch one of the backup’s presentation dates with yours. In any case, it's your responsibility to find another date and make sure you give your presentations as per the syllabus. At the end of the semester, a minimum of two presentations is required and if one is missing, you will receive a grade of 0 (if two are missing, both will be graded as 0).

examples: Do all the group members have to talk during the presentation
Do I present with someone else?

Do I have to present alone or in a group?
Presentation.answer: For presentation assignments, you present on your own and receive an individual grade from your peers. The ensuing discussion is a group activity where all group members participate and for which they receive a group mark. These are two different activities.

examples: What should my presentation include?
need help with the content of my presentation
structure of the presentation
what do I need to prepare for my presentation?
do we have to cite for the discussion presentation?
where can i find the class presentation format
What is the format of the presentation
How is the presentation evaluated?
Presentation.answer:
The main part of the presentation is about identifying the key theses (or messages) in the week's reading and then showing how the author supports them. You can start with an introduction to the thesis (which provides context or explains why the message is important or of interest) but that part is not crucial. Finally, another important part of the presentation is formulating a few questions (usually one to three) that will be put to the group for discussion. As a presenter, you don’t need to have answers to the questions. You should participate with your peers in the ensuing discussion. The evaluation criteria for the presentation are stated under “Evaluation of Presentations” under “Start”. They are:

• Preparedness
• Relevance of notes
• Comprehensiveness of notes
• Quality of the presentation
• Capacity to create a discussion
The last criterion will determine if the questions were appropriate. There is an example of what the presentation should generally look like in the “Champlain’s Humanist Ideal” module under the “In-Class” tab: see the document called “Presentation of Champlain.” If you generally follow that example and make sure to present the reading's thesis (or theses) instead of just summarizing paragraph by paragraph, you should do well.

How long should my presentation be?
Presentation.answer: Presentations should be no longer than 7 to 10 minutes, or else too little time will be left for discussion.

examples: Do I have to answer questions after the presentations?
Will be there be an Q and A after my presentation
questions after presentation
Do we answer the presentation questions as a group?
answering questions as a group after the presentation
Presentation.answer: The questions asked by the presenter are answered by the whole group. The presenter is also part of that group and should as such take an active part in the discussion. The presenter doesn’t have to have the answers when s/he asked the questions and the answer s/he might have had in mind before going to class might change with the discussion. So, the presenter is actually graded twice on the day they present: one peer-assessed grade for the presentation and one group grade for taking part in the discussion.

examples: quality of questions during the discussion
Where can I find questions to ask during the discussion
What questions can I ask during the presentation?
What kind of questions should I ask during the discussion
Should the presentation questions be long or short
list of discussion questions
I need questions for the discussion
I'm having trouble finding questions for my presentation
I dont have questions for the discussion
How in depth do the questions have to be?
can you give me some questions for the discussion
what are the discussion questions for "what is technology"?
Presentation.answer: You will be formulating questions based on the reading. Questions should help you delve deeper into the readings’ main theses. You can specify questions around the broader themes, such as “what is the author trying to say with X? What is her point(s) or message(s) regarding X.” Do you or the other students agree with the author’s claims and why? Can you go beyond the text and ask a question on how some of the author’s claims shed light on current events in Canada? Some passages may have been surprising to you and might be to other students as well. Can you use that to formulate a question? Note that these are not facts. You don’t debate facts. You debate a thesis or a message. A thesis must be defended or supported; it is up for debate and can be highlighted for discussion. Please see the examples provided in “Presentation of Champlain” in the “In-Class” tab of the “Champlain’s Humanist Ideal” module.

examples: How many times can I take the quiz

Can i retake the quiz
attempt quiz more than once
Are we allowed to attempt pre-class quizzes multiple times?
Can I complete quizzes more than once?
Quiz.answer: There is only one attempt for the quizzes and that attempt is graded. Tip: You can consult the reading before entering a final response.

examples: How are grades calculated
breakdown of my grades
Can you please explain to me how the grading works for quizzes in the grade book?
How are the quizzes graded?
Quiz.answer: All quizzes count for an equal measure toward your final grade, for a total of 10% of your grade. The first column is the proportion of the quiz grade making up your total SO FAR. The more quizzes you do, the smaller the proportion will be for each quiz. But the sum of the column will always be 100%. The second column is your grade for the quizzes (the numerator). The third column is the basis over which your grade is calculated (the denominator).

examples: How long before my quiz marks are uploaded?

My marks for quizzes are not showing up.

Quiz.answer: If you don’t see the mark for you quiz, it’s likely you didn’t click on “Finish” at the end of the quiz, and it was not graded. Tip: Make sure to click on all relevant buttons and complete your quiz before the due date and time or else you’ll get a 0 for the quiz.

examples: I need permission to take my quiz

Restriction on quizzes
I have a restriction on my quiz
How to remove a quiz restriction
Quiz.answer: Usually, a restriction on a quiz means it's too late for you to take it, resulting in a grade of 0. Quizzes close on the date and time the lecture starts. If there are extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness with doctor’s note), you should connect with the instructor to see if the quiz can be re-taken. Unfortunately, lateness due to last-minute work is not considered an acceptable reason.

examples: How do I connect to Zoom?
I need help with Zoom
how to use zoom
I cannot access Zoom
issue with my zoom connection
Log into zoom
zoom login
Zoom.answer: You may be invited to a Zoom meeting either in your eClass course or a direct invitation (this is usually an email). First, you’ll need to make sure you have your Zoom software installed. For more information on installing Zoom, visit the [How to Connect to a Zoom Meeting page](https://lthelp.yorku.ca/zoom-students/connecting-to-a-zoom-meeting-for-students). I recommend checking out the handy [Connecting to a Zoom meeting for students page](https://lthelp.yorku.ca/connecting-to-a-zoom-meeting-for-students) There you'll find information on connecting and joining meetings from Moodle or a direct invitation, hosting meetings, and more. You can also access Zoom simply by clicking on one of the links in the syllabus, under “Course Information.” There is no need for meeting ID. Just make sure to click on SSO to log in. For more information on connecting to Zoom, see the “Zoom Information” document under “Start” in eClass.

Zoom.answer: You don't have to turn on your video. It’s up to you. However, interactions would be humanized and improved if your peers could put a face to your name and voice.
